Now Shimon Peres is receiving a special Spirit of Davos award.

Asked about Iranian president Hassan Rouhani's speech yesterday, when he didn't include Israel in the group of countries which it recognised and wanted to build closer ties.

We got a smile - it's nice, but it's not an answer, says Peres. While Iran's willingness to open up is a positive, the refusal to recognise Israel is a negative.

For us Iran is not an enemy, we don't want to fight, Peres continues. It's wrong to spend so much money on military systems.

He cites South Africa's exclusion from the global community over apartheid as proof that countries will change their ways under pressure.


9.16am GMT

Some reaction to the clash between Osborne and Summers:

9.12am GMT

The session's now over -- David Cameron will be on stage in the Congress Hall soon.

9.10am GMT

Does the quality of the new jobs in the UK matter? Aren't lots of them estate   agents?

That's a bit harsh on estate agents, Osborne replies. Manufacturing jobs are rising, for perhaps the first time in his lifetime, and we can now consider raising the minimum wage because the economy is stronger. 

9.09am GMT

Osborne defends forward guidance

What does George Osborne think of the 'scribblers' in the media who have written overnight that forward guidance is a significant failure?

"I completely reject that forward guidance is a failure", Osborne replies.

The bank of England has provided clear communicatoins, supportive monetary policy,which has - alongsid the govenrment's efforts - delivered very strong data in the UNited Kingdom.

Our unemployment recovery is the equivalent of 500,000 or 600,000 new jobs in the US.

I cannot see strong unemployment data as a failure of monetary policy, Osborne continues.


9.05am GMT

When is it time to dampen the animal spirits in the UK housing market, Osborne is asked?

That's one for the Bank of England, says the chancellor, saying it has already tightened mortgage approvals and removed mortgage lending from its Funding for lending scheme.

One of the lessons of the crisis is you need to bring all these tools into the central bank -- monetary policy more than just interest rates.

Our macroprudential policy is one of the best in the world, he adds.

Updated at 9.07am GMT

9.01am GMT

9.00am GMT

Osborne defends his fiscal programme

Osborne defends himself saying:

We did have a much bigger fall in GDP [than in the US], and the impact of the crisis was even harder because our banking sector was a larger share of the economy than in America.

The great recession in the UK had an even greater effect - and we were one of the worse effected of any of the Western economies.

Summers isn't impressed, saying that "the deeper the valley you're in, the more rapidly you're able to grow.

But we have a shared interest in emphasising our points of agreement, despite the best efffots of our moderators, Summers jokes.

And that common ground includes the importance of stimulating demand through increased investment.

Updated at 9.00am GMT

8.54am GMT

Summers criticises UK deficit reduction plan

This is turning into a ding-dong battle between Larry Summers and George Osborne, with the former US treasury secretary criticising the UK's fiscal consolidation approach.

Summers says he and Osborne are in complete agreement on importance of stimulating private investment, and very much in agreement in the importance of public investment.

But then he points to the US context - the right investment strategies are win-win-win - you grow the economy, they grow the tax base, collect more revenue and substantially pay for themselves.

Look, we'll fix Kennedy Airport one day -- let's do it now and avoid a future fiscal burden.

I see less need to impose cuts on people who are vulnerable in the US context than the chancellor sees in the European context.

And then he claims Osborne is wrong to use the eurozone debt crisis.

Those rising borrowing costs were due to the specific nature of the eurozone currency -- Summers says, such as the fixed exchange rate and no individual central banks.

And while he's gratified to see growth in the UK now, it would have done better to follow the American approach.

It's several years since the US exceeded its peak GDP before the crisis -- that still hasn't happened in the UK.



Updated at 8.56am GMT

8.45am GMT

Are businesses reluctant to spend because they don't believe you'll stay in office to complete your plan?

<audience laughs>

Osborne says he has a vested interest in remaining in office to complete the job.

And he points to projects such as the new nuclear programme at Hinkley, and plans for fracking, to show that the UK government is "are prepared to take difficult decisions" that will let infrastructure spending flow.

Updated at 8.48am GMT

8.42am GMT

Osborne responds on infrastructure spending

Now a question for George Osborne on the minimum wage -- are firms profiting on the back of welfare? (because tax credit are topping up smaller pay packets)?

Why, when we're almost at the Bank of England's threshold, do we not see confidence from business sector to invest?

Osborne responds to Larry Summers comments , saying that he agrees there is an infrastructure deficit - we should be spending more on transport infrastructure and science.

But there is no "free lunch" - you need to take tough decisions elsewhere in your budgets, in areas such as welfare spending.

Without a credible fiscal policy, as many other countries learned in this crisis, you don't have a credible monetary policy and your market rates go up.

So while infrastructure spending is need, you need to make "hard choices" as finance minister as how to pay for it.

And after the "near-death" experience of the euro, businesses have been sitting on their cash, Osborne added.

8.36am GMT

Kuroda: it's not time to stop our stimulus programe

Back to Japan's central bank governor Kuroda -- how will you unwind your massive bond-buying programme?

Inflation is only halfway to our 2% target, he replies, so it's not time to stop our stimulus yet.

We are carefully watching how the Fed is handling its normalisation process.

The Fed has handled the situation pretty well  he says -- without causing disruption in the markets.

We will handle our normalisation process carefully, and not cause a negative market reaction, he pledges.

Geoff Cutmore points out that the Fed only did well on it's second go at tapering its bond-buying programme.

8.32am GMT

Swiss central bank Thomas Jordan remains a critic of forward guidance on monetary policy - saying too much detail can confuse the markets.

8.31am GMT

Asked about the impact of US tapering, Brazil central bank governor Alexandre Tombini says that it will be a net positive in the long term, despite short-term problems.

8.29am GMT

Larry Summers also pointed out that the US is spending much less on life sciences than before the crisis.

Some instant reaction:

8.26am GMT

Summers: Governments should be spending on infrastructure

Summers then outlines his fears over secular stagnation -- saying we're have effectively been no new jobs created in the US since the crisis began.

Will there be a new debt ceiling fight?

We will not see the kind of brinkmanship we saw before, Summers says.

He then argues passionately for an increase in government spending to create more growth and drive down unemployment.

If we can borrow at 3% for 30 years, and unemployment in construction in in double digits, " If this isn't the moment to fix Kennedy airport, when will it come?"

<some laughs in the audience>

Summers says that while its funny on one level, in other ways it's not:

It's tragic that we are bequeathing our children a deficit in the form of massive deferred maintenance on our infrastructure.

That looks like overt criticism of George Osborne's deficit reduction plan.


Updated at 8.27am GMT

8.20am GMT

Larry Summers: London Summit helped calm crisis

Now Larry Summers, former US treasury secretary, is asked whether the huge monetary stimulus programmes did any good.

He says they helped avoid a repeat of the Great Depression.

The last four years have been nothing like the 1929-1933 period - that's a tribute to the decisions taken by president Obama and in other countries around the world, says Summers.

If you had known at the start of the crisis how bad it would be, people would have expected much more protectionism than we've seen, adding:

﻿I give credit to our British friends for the London summit in March 2009 where that principle was established.

That's a tribute to Gordon Brown, the former UK PM, who organised that summit.

8.15am GMT

Onto Japan's central bank governor, Haruhiko Kuroda -- should we be concerned that the looming sales tax hike will scupper the Japanese recovery?

Kuroda argues that it will not, as monetary policy has taken account of the looming sales tax rise.

Japan's economy is growing at 3% - so even after the sales tax takes place, in 2 stages, the economy will still grow at 1% to 1.5% percent, which is well over Japan's medium term trend, Kuroda says.

But could it be reversed if it does cause problems?

Kuroda says that it's natural to expect households to spend more before the tax rise occurs, and then spend less afterwards. So, no knee-jerk reaction.


8.10am GMT

So are you sleeping more easily, chancellor?

Osborne replies that:

There's a huge amount to be done to fix the damage done by the great recession, and to avoid the mistakes of the past.

8.09am GMT

Osborne: Recovery is underway

Cutmore asks George Osborne to comment on Mark Carney's interview last night where he said interest rates would not rise anytime soon in the UK, even though the unemployment rate is near the 7% threshold in Carney's forward guidance.

I'm not his boss, for one thing, says Osborne, and he can't comment on monetary policy -- that's the MPC's job.

The fact we're discussing  exiting stimulus is a sign of success, it's a sign of an economy taking off.

We are only having this discussion because the recovery is underway, unemployment is falling, says Osborne.

However the job is not done, it's not even half-done,  Osborne adds -- we need to work on ways of moving to a situation where businesses provide more investment to stimulate the economy.

And the Bank of England have tools to prevent a housing bubble.


Updated at 8.37am GMT

8.04am GMT

 Haruhiko Kuroda is the man sharpening the tips of Japanese prime minister Abe's arrows, Cutmore adds.

Updated at 8.05am GMT

8.04am GMT

Introducing the panel, CNBC's Geoff Cutmore jokes that George Osborne picked Mark Carney to run the Bank of England because he realised you need a foreign manager to get success. And look, the economy is growing and unemployment is falling.

8.02am GMT

Davos debate: monetary policy

OK, the first session on the future of monetary policy is starting now. It's being streamed live here.

7.56am GMT

If you've not already enjoyed it, do check out Larry and Jill's  report of a session yesterday at Davos on meditation, led by US actress Goldie Hawn.

﻿Two bits of advice are being offered to those gazing at their difficult thoughts. Do not try to hide away from the problem and equally do not try to explode it like a time bomb. Much better to let it melt away – "slowly melting like the frost under the morning sun".   

And breathe ... Goldie Hawn and a monk teach meditation to the elite  

 

7.50am GMT

In Davos, Chile's finance minister is  insisting that his country can ride out any turmoil from neighbours, such as Argentina's currency crisis. The BBC's Alice Baxter has the details:

7.25am GMT

George Soros on Syria's humanitarian catastrophe

Something different from George Soros this year, at his traditional dinner at the WEF last night (reports Larry Elliott)

Normally, the Davos faithful flock to hear what the legendary financier thinks will be the next global currency to tank.

This year, though, Soros used his dinner to focus exclusively on the humanitarian crisis in Syria, where the civil war has caused untold suffering.

Soros said:

"International governance has failed."

"We can't ignore the victims. The attention of the global community is lacking in Syria. It is a human catastrophe of the first order."

Soros said international public opinion could affect the behaviour of the Assad regime, which he accused of pursuing a policy of "surrender or starve".   

7.22am GMT

Yesterday's speech by Australian prime minister Tony Abbott has caused a political storm back home -- the opposition Labor party are furious that it included criticism of its fiscal policy while in office.

As Katharine Murphy explains:

Labor had delivered a stimulus package during the global financial crisis, and kept spending, because the then government had a philosophy of “spending its way to prosperity”, the prime minister argued. The new Coalition government in Canberra was pro-market and small government.

There is a convention in Australian politics that domestic issues stay at home when leaders embark on overseas visits, and Labor on Friday argued Abbott would be better placed to respect it.

Tony Abbott ‘embarrassing’ in Davos, says Bill Shorten   

7.16am GMT

Davos Day 3

Hello from Davos, Switzerland, where day three of the World Economic Forum is getting underway.

There's a packed list of speakers today -- kicking off with a debate on the future of monetary policy in under an hour, at 9am Swiss time (8am GMT). UK chancellor George Osborne, Japan's finance minister  central bank governor Haruhiko Kuroda, Brazil's Alexandre Tombini, Swiss central bank chairman Thomas Jordan, and professor Larry Summers are all on the panel.

Hopefully they'll give views on the alarming tumble in the Argentinian peso's value this week.

That's followed by David Cameron's special address (10.30am Swiss time).

Al Gore, Ban Ki-moon, and Bill Gates are all on a panel discussing growth and development at 11am.

At 12, Wolfgang Schauble, Germany's finance minister, discusses the outlook for Germany.

And in the afternoon we get special addresses from Brazilian president Dilma Rousseff (2.15pm), US secretary of state John Kerry (5.15pm) and ECB president Mario Draghi (6pm).



Updated at 8.11am GMT
fields.byline: Graeme Wearden (in Davos) and Sean Farrell
fields.bodyText: And that's all for tonight from us - thanks for reading and commenting (always appreciated). GW Earlier today, David Cameron was outlining the importance of the post 2015 development goals at Davos. Oxfam have just responded, criticising the goals for failing to include a target to cut inequality -- the key theme of this year's Davos. Emma Seery, Oxfam senior policy adviser, said: "We welcome the PM's push for global goals to tackle corruption and promote democracy. But this week's Davos discussions have revealed the absence of a target to reduce inequality to be a gaping hole at the heart of the current post-2015 proposal." Draghi's final comment on the eurozone stress tests might send a shiver through weaker banks -- ﻿"Shedding light on banks' balance sheets should help them raise capital in the market. And of course banks that should go, should go." Argentina's currency woes have reawakened fears of problems in emerging markets and sent investors scurrying for cover, writes Nick Fletcher. With stock markets at or near record highs, the news was enough to bring out the profit takers. So the closing scores were as follows: • The FTSE 100 finished 109.54 points or 1.62% lower at 6663.74, its worst week since June last year • Germany's Dax was down 2.48% at 9392.02 • France's Cac closed 2.79% lower at 4161.47 • Italy's FTSE MIB ended 2.3% down at 19,358.99 • Spain's Ibex fell 3.64% to 9868.9 As for Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently down 188 points or 1.18%. Draghi continues that he does not have any expectations on the outcome of the Asset Quality Review -- but shedding light on their balance sheets should help them raise capital. A long question about Europe's banks, and the part that politics will play in the upcoming Asset Quality Review for the eurozone banking sector: Draghi: there has been a return of confidence into the banking sector. Banks have been issuing bonds in significant amounts for some months, and the difference between what financial firms and non-financial firms pay to borrow has contracted to zero. So, its a more confident environment. And once we announced the AQR, some regulators made sure banks would reclassify their loans as non-performing, and provisions against them, or raise capital, or deleverage. This situation is "dramatically better than a year ago". So why are we doing this, Draghi continues -- we need a monetary policy that lets us achieve our goal of price stability. High fragmentation in the eurozone banking sector (ie, banks in the periphery paying more for credit than in the core) makes that process harder, he explains. The AQR should further rebuild confidence. Germany is the only country with lower youth unemployment rate since the crisis started, and inflation is below your target of close to, but below 2% -- only seven have inflation at 1% or higher, says Hildebrand. You've said you stand ready to act, Mario -- could you tell us what parts of your arsenal would be most effective if you were called to fight low inflation? Draghi agrees that eurozone inflation is below target, and will remain below for some time. But he doesn't see deflation in the eurozone -- not defined as broad-based falls in prices across the eurozone. Medium-term inflation expectations are firmly anchored at 2%, he adds. And core inflation is being pulled down by the rates of the four 'programme countries' -- that is probably partly due to the internal rebalancing. In that case, it's a temporary effect. (this all sounds rather like an ECB press conference) Draghi is now arguing that countries did the easiest thing when they entered fiscal consolidation programmes under a crisis: namely raising taxes "in a part of the world where taxes are already high", with little progress on cutting government expenditure and huge cuts in capital expenditure. So now we have to make these fiscal consolidation programmes more growth-friendly - less taxes, less government expenditure, more expenditure on infrastructure. We should also give a medium-term perspective to this fiscal consolidation, which seems to have been successful as a way to go in the UK, for example, he adds. Draghi also cites youth unemployment as an example that labour markets must be reformed. Philipp Hildebrand says there has been tremendous readjustment in peripheral euro countries in recent years. But then he cites an OECD report into which countries have made the most reforms -- Germany comes last, while countries who have been through a reform programme are at the top. Is the crisis over in the periphery? And should we be worried that in two years there will be a crisis in the core? Draghi replies that Germany is last because it made these reforms 10 years ago. But all countries need structural reforms. Draghi agrees that countries such as Greece have made good progress on structural reforms. But other peripheral countries have not done as much. Also have some core countries who need to reform - that's not because they did it 10 years ago, but because they've not done it. No country is named -- but France (sick man or not) must be on the list. Draghi said European leaders also deserve credit for the eurozone recovery, citing the commitment taken in summer 2012 to develop banking union. I said something else in London (in the whatever it takes speech) that has not been well reported, he adds, that the markets were "vastly underestimating the amount of political commitment" that European countries has put into making the euro a success. The bottom line is this, says Mario Draghi: ﻿ We are seeing the beginning of a recovery that is still weak, still fragile, and still uneven. Still based on exports, but there are signs of a recovery in domestic demand. But unemployment is still far too high, and risks remain to the downside. Philipp Hildebrand of BlackRock, who is chairing the session, tells Draghi that Larry Summers recently compared him to Churchill: Never in the history of financial markets have so few words and even less action done so much for so many. Draghi agrees that stock prices have risen sharply since he pledged to do whatever it takes to save the euro, while bond yields (borrowing costs) have fallen. Risks have decreased all across the board, for core countries and those in the periphery, Draghi adds. And there are signs that the recovery is finally reaching the real economy, with encouraging surveys. But the hard data is not so good. Mario Draghi is being introduced at Davos now, as among the best experienced, best educated central bankers in the world. He has guided us through the biggest financial and economic crisis since the Great Depression, says Klaus Schwab. It's being streamed here. French finance minister has condemned "foolish" claims that France is now the sick man of Europe as "caricature and prejudice", insisting that Paris is determined to improve its economy. Pierre Moscovici told reporters at Davos that when he looks at the performances between Great Britain and France since 2008, "I'd prefer to be French". ﻿We are the same level of production [GDP] as in 2008 - it's not too great, but it's better than Great Britain. Moscovici added that while Great Britain appears to have a better dynamism today, that may be because "the situation before was not so fine", continuing: If being the sick man of Europe is being the 5th economy in the world, with GDP higher than Great Britain, the second economy in Europe, with capacities for education, for innovation, for investment, for creation, well, it's good to be sick. Moscovici said that "I know that we have problems", citing the need to create more jobs, fight unemployment, raise competitiveness and cut the public debt (which France's own state auditor fears is dangerously high at over 93% of GDP). adding: ﻿But I make a difference between bashing - bashing is the "foolish idea" that we are the sick man of Europe, that we are a vanishing country, that we are falling down. This makes no sense at all. We are a solid country. ﻿My job is to solve problems, but it's also to fight against caricatures and prejudices. Saying France is a sick man is a caricature and a prejudice. saying France needs to improve its economy is the truth, and it's exactly what we're doing. John Kerry insisted that president Assad must step down - there can be no chance of peace in Syria otherwise. And he expressed deep concern about the terrorism threat in the region,saying that Syria is the world's greatest single magnet for Jihad and terror. But military action is not the solution to the conflict, he added. Just been in a press conference with French finance minister Pierre Moscovici ( of which more in a moment!). John Kerry is giving his set-piece speech now -- expressing solidarity with the people of Ukraine, and warning that the hard work with Iran starts now: We'll have details shortly, but in the meantime here are the key points: Sir Martin Sorrell, the boss of the WPP advertising group, has told David Cameron that he'd be a "shoo-in" to return to Downing Street in 2015, if he dropped his pledge for a referendum on Britain's place in Europe. Speaking at the CBI's lunch for business leaders, Sorrell said there would be a "very good economic backdrop " next year, with growth of 2.5% per year, perhaps higher. But Cameron risks blowing that advantage by putting the UK's place in the EU in doubt, Sorrell warned, saying that the business community believes Britain should stay part of Europe. While the Labour Party is "taking politics to the left", Sorrell said, Ed Miliband does believe Britain should remain in the EU. He declared: ﻿"If the Conservative Party said it was against a referendum after the election, it would be a shoo-in" (quotes via Larry Elliott who was at the lunch) There's also plenty of reaction to David Cameron's speech calling on UK companies to bring manufacturing home under the banner Reshore UK. Lee Hopley, chief economist at EEF, the manufacturers’ organisation, said the government needed to work more closely with the EU, which may not be music to his ears: First and foremost, the UK must provide a competitive cost base, skills in sufficient numbers and certainty about the returns over the lifetime of those investments if we are to secure the benefits of this trend. The Prime Minister set out some of what the government is doing to achieve this but there is still work to be done. Not least in our engagement with Europe. His focus on a pro-business, pro-growth agenda in Europe is welcome, the UK needs to ensure it keeps that agenda on track to make greater levels of re-shoring back to Europe and the UK a reality. Neil Rami, head of Business Birmingham, the city’s inward investment agency, welcomed the speech but brought up some other bugbears for the PM – immigration restrictions and high energy costs: Re-shoring can help forge the new economy, creating jobs and cutting our trade deficit. We have seen that in Birmingham with Jaguar Land Rover, who will open a £500m factory in Wolverhampton next month with 1,400 staff. The launch of Reshore UK is a very welcome step. It shows we are serious about bringing business back to these shores and will help reverse the trend of production and jobs being sent abroad. Restrictive regulations – such as visa regulation and commercial regulations – and high energy costs are big barriers which need to be pulled down. SF Our economics team have been taking a closer look at the coalition's claims that UK take-home pay is rising for most people. Here's what they say: The government numbers are old and cover April 2012 to April 2013. After then, pay growth fell considerably. The latest official data put it at 0.9%, down from 1.4% a year earlier. The numbers do not cover the self-employed, whose numbers have grown due to redundancies and cuts to hours in the downturn. There are 500,000 more self-employed than before the crisis. At least one real take-home pay survey suggests pay still falling for many workers and for many it is down more than 7% since the start of the recession. The government's view is not a complete analysis of how well-off people feel as it doesn't cover benefits changes and therefore not their disposable income. Scott Corfe, an economist at the Centre for Economics and Business Research (Cebr), said: ﻿“It’s interesting that the figures relate to 2012 to 2013. It was really in 2013 that we saw pay growth start to fall quite sharply. Earnings growth fell in 2013. I think the picture would be very different if you looked at 2013-14. I think it would be worse.” ONS data on average weekly earnings – not the data used by the government in its analysis – cover a much more recent period and show earnings growth failing to come even close to keeping pace with inflation. Inflation has come down to be back at its target of 2% in December from 2.1% in November. That was still double the pace of average earnings growth, which was 0.9% in September to November 2013, down sharply from earnings growth of 1.4% a year earlier. Cebr’s Corfe compiles a monthly take-home pay report for the salary processing company VocaLink. Its latest numbers this week showed workers in the public sector and manufacturing continued to see their take-home pay fall in real terms. The squeeze was the toughest for public sector workers who are £23 a month worse off than a year earlier in real terms, according to VocaLink, which processes salary payments for much of the British workforce. Some experts do believe pay patterns are improving. Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit Williamson said Markit’s monthly household finances index showed some pick up in people’s total pay but he questioned whether hourly pay was actually rising: I think pay is up more than the official data is showing at the moment and we will even start to see those numbers start to improve in 2014. We are definitely hearing that people are earning more – not necessarily their pay rates but they are taking home more pay because they are getting more hours and little bonuses. SF Anna Maria Corazza Bild, the Swedish MEP who challenged David Cameron on immigration this morning, has warned that the PM is "playing with fire" Speaking to Jill Treanor, she warned that: This rhetoric has consequences... A Romanian and a Belgian in Britain is not a migrant. A British passport holder who was born in Rome, Bild said Cameron appeared to be saying the UK wanted to remain in the EU under renegotiated terms, one of which was the restriction of movement. Reaction to Mark Carney's speech is streaming in. The CBI approves and says business needs more time before rates start to rise: CBI director general John Cridland said this: ﻿There are increasing signs that the economy is back on track and the investment cycle now needs to turn. This should boost productivity and go hand-in-hand with the growing number of jobs. With slack in the labour market and inflationary pressures easing, but productivity not yet rising, business will welcome the Governor’s comments on interest rates. Interest rates should remain low to help sustain the recovery. Howard Archer at IHS Global Insight points out that MPC members have been out on manoeuvres in a "communications offensive" to make sure the "no rate rise" message sticks: MPC members Paul Fisher, Ian McCafferty and Martin Weale have all stressed in speeches and newspaper articles over the last couple of days that interest rates could stay at 0.50% for some considerable time after the unemployment rate gets down to 7.0% and lower... While it is not clear yet how the Bank of England will update its forward guidance policy, it looks like strong communication will be a major part of the bank’s efforts to limit interest rate hike expectations given the high visibility of MPC members in recent days. And here, via Twitter, is some insight from the Telegraph's cartoon investment banker Alex Masterley: SF No time for a Q&A with president Rousseff, so Klaus Schwab thanks her for the speech, saying her words on foreign investment should have reassured the room. We hope you and your government score as many goals as possible, he concludes. President Rousseff said "I invites you all to join us" in increasing Brazil's foreign investment, and then adds that she also invites delegates to the upcoming World Cup and the 2016 Olympics. Rousseff ends by insisting that Brazil is "poised and ready for the upcoming World Cup" (despite concerns that stadiums will not be ready in time). Football, she says, can be a powerful weapon to fight discrimination. We have our arms wide open to welcome visitors from all over the world. Rousseff welcomes the "historic deal reached" at the World Trade Association recently. And she argues again that countries such as Brazil need not be hurt by the Federal Reserve tapering, saying: ﻿A new world economic growth cycle is now under gestation. As the crisis recedes, we will certainly see emerging markets see new attention. With a long-term strategy focused on fostering investment, on education, and on increased productivity we hope to come out of the current business crisis even better off. She says Brazil wants to encourage more foreign investment partnerships -"We have always welcomed foreign investment". President Rousseff explains how Brazil will continue to work with private-sector firms - both from Brazil and overseas. We have held five highway auctions, transferring over 4,000 km to private sector hands. Concession deals for 6 airports granted to consortiums led by large private corporations We will obtain $28bn through the life of these partnerships, We will authorise new privately run ports in 2014, she pledges. ﻿Brazil is a country that is as vast as a continent, so we need a proper railway system, especially for grain and ore outflow, and for container transport. We'll hold our first auction for one stretch of railway in 2014, she says. We do not compromise on inflation, she continues. Inflation remains under control in Brazil, Rousseff continues, and we are purposefully aiming for the mid-point in our inflation target. Dilma Rousseff moves onto the issue of last year's protests in Brazil - saying they were actually an important part of the country's journey. Citizens have a better understanding of their rights, and have new demands, she says. Some of these new Brazilian citizens were in last June's demonstrations out on the streets. Those demonstrations were an "inseparable part of our process of building democracy and fostering social change". "My administration did not crack down on those demonstrations. On the contrary we heard and we understood the voices of the street," she says. Those protesters wanted more rights , argues Rousseff, saying once people have experienced democracy, social inclusion and quality of life they want more. Brazil's transformation in recent years has pushed millions more up to the middle classs. We have created 4.5m new jobs in the last few years, and we are creating a mass consumer market. 45% have a computer 55% have an automatic washing machine 17% have a freezer 8% have a flatscreen TV This clearly shows the size of the consumer demand still to be met, she insists Dilma Rousseff rattles through the economic history of the last few years, and then argues that the recovery in the developed economies does not mean the the emerging markets will necessarily suffer. Emerging economies will still play a strategic role -- we still offer the best opportunities for growth, and deep reserves of natural resources. To assume emerging economics will be less-dynamic in the future an over-hasty conclusion, she argues. Developed economies suffered most from the crisis, so as they emerge from the crisis they should stimulate more growth across the global economy. This is a big speech for the Brazilian president - she will want to reassure business leaders that Brazil remains a good place to invest. Klaus Schwab is introducing president Rousseff, praising her efforts on fighting social inclusion*, and welcoming her very cordially to the snow of Davos. * - no mention of the protests in Brazil last year, unsurprisingly Swiss cow bells are ringing in the congress hall, because it's time for Brazil's president, Dilma Rousseff, to give a special address. They're ringing a bit quieter now, though -- after the bell-toller was told to shush so French finance minister Pierre Moscovici could give a TV interview. Rousseff's speech will be broadcast here. A clip of David Cameron's appearance at Davos this morning: Bono has just launched a scathing attack on companies who are fighting demands for more disclosure about their activities. Sitting alongside David Cameron on the Development Goals panel (highlights start here), the rock star said: “Some of the criminals around here not wearing ski masks, they are wearing skis”. A campaigner against poverty, Bono referred to the “evil twins” that the business community needs to tackle – opacity in the extractive industry and the ability of companies to hide their assets in companies registered in secretive tax havens. US companies are now required to disclose how much they pay for mining rights – a move being restricted by some of them – while the EU is also taking steps to force companies to show their beneficial owners. Bono cited the legal battle from the American Petroleum Industry to resist having to disclose payments to foreign governments (details here). (via Jill Treanor) Amusing moment on the Development Goals panel -- starting when Prudential boss Tidjane Thiam argued that the key to development goals is to unlock private sector assets. We can invest easier than politicians, who need to get things through parliament, he argues. Prudential could put 10% of its $800bn assets into Africa. Thaim claims: ﻿What is missing is a pipeline of projects, of bankable investments opportunities. We want to invest. Nigeria's finance minister Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala responds smartly: We can give you bankable investments.... Amid laughter, the moderator steps in saying "Davos is a place for doing deals" -- tell him how you going to make Nigeria the place for his investments. They're there, she insists. "Tidjane just has to persuade his board". And Jasmine Whitbread, CEO of Save The Children, says it's also important to make as much progress on the 2015 goals over the next 700 days. About half of them have been achieved, but the second half will be harder. David Cameron smiles when the panel moderator congratulates him on including almost every major issue facing the world in the post-2015 development Agenda -- from climate change to gender equality. But shouldn't we leave a few out, to make progress on the rest? Cameron replies that you can't tackle poverty without including these issues (there are 12 goals in total). He says he's particularly pleased that the panel added goals on corruption and governance for the first time -- this is a key factor in poverty today, he says. As Cameron puts it: Why is North Korea poor and South Korea rich. It's not the weather, it's not the part of the world the're living in, it's to do with the institutions under which they live and the governments running those countries. Cameron adds that his big worry is not that there are too many goals, but that "we end up with nothing" if policymakers keep talking about these goals instead of addressing them. Nigeria's finance minister Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala agrees that the goals are important - saying the panel could easily have had 20. Elsewhere in Davos -- a star panel is discussing how to implement the goals for development and fighting poverty after 2015. It includes Nigeria's finance minister Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, Bono, David Cameron, and Prudential CEO Tidjane Thaim. It's being streamed here. More details of Mark Carney's comments on UK monetary policy, and reaction to it: Mark Carney, Bank of England governor, is telling business leaders and journalists right now that the UK economy has not yet reached 'escape velocity' . Carney also says that the Bank will update its forward guidance on future interest rate rises (now unemployment is close to its 7% target much sooner than expected). From the lunch, Larry Elliott reports that Carney pledged that the degree of stimulus would “remain exceptional for some time.” Carney added: “That should help reassure British business that the path of interest rates will be consistent with a sustained recovery – that is, with escape velocity.” The Bank has been surprised by the recent performance of the economy, having predicted last August that it could be early 2016 before the jobless rate hit 7%. “A few quarters of above-trend growth driven by household spending represent a good start, but they aren’t sufficient”, Carney said as he discussed the prospects for permanent exit from the deepest recession of the post-war era. “It will take sustained growth, more balanced demand and a recovery in the supply side for advanced economies to break free into a more normal universe.” And on forward guidance - his first big move as governor - Carney said: ﻿“The MPC will consider a range of options to update our guidance, recognising both what we have learned about the behaviour of aggregate supply in the economy as well as the more benign inflation outlook.” Other highlights from Wolfgang Schauble's session- he said France was, and remains, a strong country. And he backed David Cameron's point this morning, that Europe needs treaty change to improve the institutional structure of the eurozone. Mats Persson of the Open Europe think tank suggests that means closer controls on other country's budgets. Speaking of woods - Larry Summers attack on George Osborne's fiscal programme this morning didn't go down well with conservative party officials: Larry Elliott has written about the Osborne-Summers spat here: US secretary of state John Kerry is due to address Davos at 5.15pm -- ahead of the speech, senator John McCain has apparently warned that America's influence on world affairs is weakening. Isa Soares of CNN has the quote: Early this morning, we mentioned George Soros's concerns about the humanitarian catastrophe unfolding in Syria - an issue Kerry will surely cover in his speech. Wolfgang Schauble also touched on the issue of immigration, saying that one cause of the political instability in Greece is the flow of migrants from Africa. He says Europe must show solidarity with Greece, and develop new ways to handle migration. On Greece, Wolfgang Schauble admitted that he would not have fancied implementing such a tough austerity programme in Germany What the Greek population has had to bear is incredible. They have made progress, but they are not out of the woods, Schauble said. Back in Davos, finance minister Wolfgang Schauble has been on stage discussing the outlook for Germany, and beyond. Schauble points to the progress made in the eurozone, declaring: ﻿We are no longer the main source of concern for the financial markets. We are not completely out of it.... but we've come far. Has the crisis come to an end? No, no, no there are more efforts to be deployed. Schauble also claimed that Europe's recession would have been much worse without the "driving force" of the German economy (critics might suggest that without Germany, the euro would have been weaker and the ECB could have delivered more unconventional policies) At Davos, David Cameron mentioned Hornby as a company that has brought some manufacturing back to the UK. But the company is still suffering supply chain problems with the factories who make its products in China. Lack of supply in the last few months of 2013 will send annual sales below expectations and last year's result, the train set, Corgi car and Airfix maker warned. Along with the falling value of currency held to buy the products, the delays will cause a £1m annual loss. Hornby has been reporting these problems on and off since 2010 so surely there's a case for pleasing the PM and bringing all manufacturing back so management can just hop in the car to check everything's running smoothly. City AM's pun-laden interpretation is below. SF Markets are digesting Mark Carney's comments on forward guidance overnight at Davos. The Bank of England governor indicated to Jeremy Paxman on Newsnight that interest rates wouldn't rise in the near future, despite unemployment falling to near the BoE's 7% threshold for considering a rise. Carney is giving a speech at Davos just after midday. He seems to have stolen his own thunder by going on the telly the night before but let's see what he says. Here's what CMC Markets' Michael Hewson makes of Carney's interview: Last night’s comments shouldn’t really have been a surprise given comments he made in November last year “one could imagine a scenario where the unemployment threshold is reached and that the best policy for the MPC at that period of time is to keep rates at current levels because the trade-off between output and inflation is attractive,” he said. With inflation now at 2% the Bank is clearly playing that trade-off. Away from the glamour of Davos, Martin Weale, an external member of the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee, has been checking out the local economy in Suffolk. The East Anglian Daily Times reports that Weale, who voted against Carney's forward guidance plan, doesn't want the MPC to revise its criteria for considering a rate rise. There are no quotes from Weale in the story but this is what the paper reports: ﻿There have been suggestions the MPC should now lower the 7% threshold to, perhaps, 6.5%, but Mr Weale said he did not believe this would achieve the core aim of Forward Guidance, that of creating greater certainty, as any new threshold could also quickly be overtaken by events. However, he said the MPC had been clear all along that the unemployment rate was only one of many factors which would shape any decision to raise interest rates and, with wage increases still well below inflation, there was scope for rates to remain at their current level for a while yet. Interesting stuff, especially after Carney's interview and fellow MPC member Paul Fisher's speech yesterday when he said he couldn't see an "immediate need" to increase rates. MPC members are free to express their individual views – or is this a coordinated message to the market? SF Back in the UK, the big company story is Royal Mail's trading statement covering Christmas. It's the first time the group has reported this all-important period since it floated last year. The overall message is that everything's in line with expectations and Royal Mail is on track for its full-year targets. Investors are a bit underwhelmed: after rising early on, the shares are down 0.5%, in line with the market, at 584.5p. That's still almost 80% up on October's 330p flotation price. In the nine months to the end of December, like-for-like revenue was up 2% and parcels made up 51% of revenue. Parcels are important for Royal Mail because that's where the growth is, fuelled by people buying online, while letter sales are falling as we switch to email and, more recently, social media. In UK parcels, revenue was up 8% as Royal Mail charged more for bigger items but volumes were flat. Consumer volumes fell as people held off posting big items made more expensive by the size-based pricing. Here's what chief executive Moya Greene said: We remained the nation's number one parcel delivery company, handling 115 million parcels in the month of December alone. That's significantly more than any other carrier in the UK parcel market. GLS, our ground-based European parcels business, has performed well and is exploiting the growth opportunities in the Eurozone. Our financial performance to date is in line with our expectations and gives us confidence that we will deliver against our key value drivers for the full year. SF To recap, the British PM has told world leaders and business men and women that the UK, and Europe, can reshore jobs back home, and declared that shale gas energy help drive the recovery. Speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos (highlights start here), David Cameron said it was wrong to think European countries are in terminal decline because of globalisation, saying: Whether it's the shift from manufacturing to services or the transfer from manual jobs to machines, the end point is the same dystopian vision - the East wins while the West loses; and the workers lose while the machines win. I don't believe it has to be this way. "Of course, we shouldn't be starry-eyed about globalisation - it presents huge challenges as our economies and societies try to adapt - but neither should we take this pessimistic view. Britain, he declared, can be the Reshore Nation. He wants European countries to step up to the challenges, by reducing regulatory burden on firms and reforming labour markets. Cameron also insisted that Europe must embrace shale gas, and learn from the US: ﻿There is no doubt that when it comes to re-shoring in the US, one of the most important factors has been the development of shale gas. And during a lively Q&A session, Cameron said he backed the living wage, but only for those organisations who can afford it; and defended his position on immigration from new EU member states. And that's the end of the session. The final question is a corker -- with a top executive from the Hinduja Group telling Cameron that he's been coming to Davos for 25 years, and seen leaders from the days of Edward Heath. The British, I know, are the best brains in the world. This is my experience, I don't know what the rest of the world thinks about it.... So why not focus your poverty programmes on Africa to get more progress? Cameron thanks the compliment paid to his fellow countrymen. He won't take the compliment personally, as: ﻿I work with a lot of people who are a lot brighter than I am, and I see that every day. Cameron says he's proud that his government sticks to his promise of paying 0.7% of GDP in aid. Aid can do an enormous amount, fighting disease and helping people out of poverty. But it also gives us an opportunity to make arguments about the other things that hold countries back, says Cameron. Countries who made the jump from poverty to success are those who include people in development, he says. We need to be franker and tougher in fighting corruption, enforcing the rule of law, backing democratic institutions -- what he dubs The Golden Thread that runs through development. A Lufthansa executive asks Cameron how he'll change his economic policies if Scotland quits the Union and Britain quits the EU. Cameron says Scotland and the rest of Britain are stronger and safer together, and the message is getting through, And on Europe, the PM says: ﻿I'm confident we'll have a successful renegotiation and a successful referendum. The eurozone needs change, he says. Not a single currency in the world that can cope without common fiscal policy, banking union, and the current treaties don't allow it. We can seize the opportunity to reshape our relationship with EU. Excellent, Cameron takes a question from Frances Grady of the TUC. She welcomes Cameron's suggestion that Reshoring could bring back well-paid jobs - is he backing the TUC living wage campaign? Cameron replies that if we get our economic policy right, our labour market right, if there is flexibility, then we can return jobs at all levels of pay. We've made 4 new private sector jobs for each public sector one lost. Employers who can afford a living wage should pay it, Cameron says, and pays tribute to Boris Johnson for implementing it at City Hall. I want people paid more, but we need to show we are succeeding with productivity and output. If you implement the living wage across the country, then you could cost jobs not make them. I support it, but people should pay it when they can afford it, and around the country you are seeing people like councils offering it. Cameron says he welcomes widening the EU to more members, alongside the new measures on migratory reforms. Right, onto questions, and a Swedish MEP asks Cameron to justify his recent comments on migration. And she also asks him to tell his colleagues in the European parliament to be more constructive to make progress. You are a key player - you would achieve smarter regulation if you work with us, rather than undermine us. Cameron says one of Britain's roles in the world is to speak clearly on things it agrees with, and disagrees with. He defends his European Parliament MEPs for doing a good job fighting regulation. And on immigration -- The right to move within European Union and apply for jobs is an important freedom which he supports. But, It should not be a right to move to claim benefits. I make absolutely no apology for tightening UK welfare system so it can't be abused. When Britain allowed new members to the EU in 2004 without a transition period, 1.5m people moved here. The biggest migration in recent history, says Cameron I say with future accessions, we need new transitional controls, longer transitional periods. And he points out that the situation changes when you are looking at countries with very different GDP levels, than those with similar ones. He dubs his position "Practical good Conservative common sense, and that's something the EU needs a lot of". A few laughs in the room. Now onto another popular issue for Cameron - fracking. Done properly, he argues, shale gas can deliver affordable energy with less environmental damage than many other sources. And he warns that the EC is still proposing too much regulation, despite recent changes. If Europe puts too much burden on shale industry, then producers will go elsewhere and Europe will be dry. Don't hold back on telling governments what they need to do, he urges business people in the world. What do we need to get reshoring to work? Cameron outlines some predictable themes -- cutting red tape, reducing burden on companies, and also reforming labour markets. He cites a big investment deal in Spain which was achieved after the Spanish unions agreed to recast working conditions. Cameron says he's not claiming that there are a finite number of jobs in the world; and he's not suggesting that UK firms will turn their back on the world. I'm not saying we are going on a race to the bottom , says Cameron, insisting that reshoring can create permanent, high quality jobs. Europe has an opportunity to accelerate this trend of jobs coming back home. Cameron also says that Europe must never sell the right enshrined in liberal democracy, saying he tells bosses in Davos to check how often a country's government loses court cases before deciding if it's safe to invest there. Sadly in Britain it's far too often, he adds, but that shows we respect the rule of law. Cameron cites several factors driving US companies back 'onshore'. Pay, especially executive pay, has risen in countries such as China, and a shorter supply chain helps firms get products into the shops fast. He also claims that the US push into shale fracking has also encouraged firms back into America. The UK can do the same, he says: ﻿There is a chance for Britain to become the Reshore Nation. But now, there's an opportunity for jobs that have gone abroad in recent years to come home, Cameron says, reversing the recent trend. Surveys show this is happening already in some industries, he says. He cites several firms who have moved manufacturing back home, such as trainmaker Hornby and the Raspberry Pi computer firm. Cameron hails inward investment, such as India with Jaguar Landrover and China with our new nuclear deal at Hinkley In a time of austerity, we chose to keep investing in science. We cut corporation tax, especially those for firms investing in the UK. Britian is open, pionerring, innovative, and ready for your investment, says the PM. Cameron outlines the UK's economic programme, key points include: Controlling debts Getting welfare and immigration under control improving schools for young people to help them get jobs Better infrastructure and lower taxes for businesses Cameron points out that the IMF has raised its growth forecasts, and unemployment is down again, because the UK is focusing on its strengths. The key challenge is how do European countries tackle globalisation, says Cameron. For years, critics have been saying that Europe is in terminal decline, from the twin threats of developing nations and emerging technologies. That's wrong, he says. Need to get fundamentals of our economies back -- tackle our debts, make our economies competitive, we can succeed and sell goods around the world. Get it right and jobs that have been sent around the globe can come home, says Cameron. Cameron starts by joking that he's been through the seven-year itch at Davos, and decided to stick with the relationship in year eight. Right, David Cameron is now on stage -- it's his eighth Davos in a row. It is being streamed live here. After a standing ovation, the Israeli president is presented with a special cowbell - a signature of Davos - rather than a mere medal. WEF founder Klaus Schwab said Peres is being recognised for "Tolling the bell of peace and harmony". Peres promptly grasps the bell and gives it a good ring now, saying he wants to go around the Middle East ringing it as a call to peace. Shimon Peres describes himself as a dissatisfied optimist, as he contrasts the vision of what can be done with the reality today. And he exalts those in the room to devote themselves to work, not to entertainment. The greatest interest and the greatest entertainment, is in working. Do it right, and you'll be happier than you'd think, he concludes. Shimon Peres is giving a captivating speech on the future, explaining how aid to the developing world must change because much of the money goes to the rich not the poor. And how technology, such as small, cheap computers, will bring massive changes to the developing world. I'll try to get the whole text later.... Terrorists are flooding into Syria, says Peres, and Iran must share the blame for the situation, Peres continues, for sending Hezbollah into the country. He's arguing that the future for the Middle East must lie with young people across the region. The current crisis in the Middle East is tearing the region to pieces -- there is no coherent country today, say Peres. And on Syria, he says that "all the elements in Syria are not elements for solutions, but are elements for confrontation". We need a new element - made of two parts, the younger generation and science. Now Shimon Peres is receiving a special Spirit of Davos award. Asked about Iranian president Hassan Rouhani's speech yesterday, when he didn't include Israel in the group of countries which it recognised and wanted to build closer ties. We got a smile - it's nice, but it's not an answer, says Peres. While Iran's willingness to open up is a positive, the refusal to recognise Israel is a negative. For us Iran is not an enemy, we don't want to fight, Peres continues. It's wrong to spend so much money on military systems. He cites South Africa's exclusion from the global community over apartheid as proof that countries will change their ways under pressure. Some reaction to the clash between Osborne and Summers: The session's now over -- David Cameron will be on stage in the Congress Hall soon. Does the quality of the new jobs in the UK matter? Aren't lots of them estate agents? That's a bit harsh on estate agents, Osborne replies. Manufacturing jobs are rising, for perhaps the first time in his lifetime, and we can now consider raising the minimum wage because the economy is stronger. What does George Osborne think of the 'scribblers' in the media who have written overnight that forward guidance is a significant failure? "I completely reject that forward guidance is a failure", Osborne replies. The bank of England has provided clear communicatoins, supportive monetary policy,which has - alongsid the govenrment's efforts - delivered very strong data in the UNited Kingdom. Our unemployment recovery is the equivalent of 500,000 or 600,000 new jobs in the US. I cannot see strong unemployment data as a failure of monetary policy, Osborne continues. When is it time to dampen the animal spirits in the UK housing market, Osborne is asked? That's one for the Bank of England, says the chancellor, saying it has already tightened mortgage approvals and removed mortgage lending from its Funding for lending scheme. One of the lessons of the crisis is you need to bring all these tools into the central bank -- monetary policy more than just interest rates. Our macroprudential policy is one of the best in the world, he adds. Osborne defends himself saying: We did have a much bigger fall in GDP [than in the US], and the impact of the crisis was even harder because our banking sector was a larger share of the economy than in America. The great recession in the UK had an even greater effect - and we were one of the worse effected of any of the Western economies. Summers isn't impressed, saying that "the deeper the valley you're in, the more rapidly you're able to grow. But we have a shared interest in emphasising our points of agreement, despite the best efffots of our moderators, Summers jokes. And that common ground includes the importance of stimulating demand through increased investment. This is turning into a ding-dong battle between Larry Summers and George Osborne, with the former US treasury secretary criticising the UK's fiscal consolidation approach. Summers says he and Osborne are in complete agreement on importance of stimulating private investment, and very much in agreement in the importance of public investment. But then he points to the US context - the right investment strategies are win-win-win - you grow the economy, they grow the tax base, collect more revenue and substantially pay for themselves. Look, we'll fix Kennedy Airport one day -- let's do it now and avoid a future fiscal burden. I see less need to impose cuts on people who are vulnerable in the US context than the chancellor sees in the European context. And then he claims Osborne is wrong to use the eurozone debt crisis. Those rising borrowing costs were due to the specific nature of the eurozone currency -- Summers says, such as the fixed exchange rate and no individual central banks. And while he's gratified to see growth in the UK now, it would have done better to follow the American approach. It's several years since the US exceeded its peak GDP before the crisis -- that still hasn't happened in the UK. Are businesses reluctant to spend because they don't believe you'll stay in office to complete your plan?  Osborne says he has a vested interest in remaining in office to complete the job. And he points to projects such as the new nuclear programme at Hinkley, and plans for fracking, to show that the UK government is "are prepared to take difficult decisions" that will let infrastructure spending flow. Now a question for George Osborne on the minimum wage -- are firms profiting on the back of welfare? (because tax credit are topping up smaller pay packets)? Why, when we're almost at the Bank of England's threshold, do we not see confidence from business sector to invest? Osborne responds to Larry Summers comments , saying that he agrees there is an infrastructure deficit - we should be spending more on transport infrastructure and science. But there is no "free lunch" - you need to take tough decisions elsewhere in your budgets, in areas such as welfare spending. Without a credible fiscal policy, as many other countries learned in this crisis, you don't have a credible monetary policy and your market rates go up. So while infrastructure spending is need, you need to make "hard choices" as finance minister as how to pay for it. And after the "near-death" experience of the euro, businesses have been sitting on their cash, Osborne added. Back to Japan's central bank governor Kuroda -- how will you unwind your massive bond-buying programme? Inflation is only halfway to our 2% target, he replies, so it's not time to stop our stimulus yet. We are carefully watching how the Fed is handling its normalisation process. The Fed has handled the situation pretty well he says -- without causing disruption in the markets. We will handle our normalisation process carefully, and not cause a negative market reaction, he pledges. Geoff Cutmore points out that the Fed only did well on it's second go at tapering its bond-buying programme. Swiss central bank Thomas Jordan remains a critic of forward guidance on monetary policy - saying too much detail can confuse the markets. Asked about the impact of US tapering, Brazil central bank governor Alexandre Tombini says that it will be a net positive in the long term, despite short-term problems. Larry Summers also pointed out that the US is spending much less on life sciences than before the crisis. Some instant reaction: Summers then outlines his fears over secular stagnation -- saying we're have effectively been no new jobs created in the US since the crisis began. Will there be a new debt ceiling fight? We will not see the kind of brinkmanship we saw before, Summers says. He then argues passionately for an increase in government spending to create more growth and drive down unemployment. If we can borrow at 3% for 30 years, and unemployment in construction in in double digits, " If this isn't the moment to fix Kennedy airport, when will it come?"  Summers says that while its funny on one level, in other ways it's not: It's tragic that we are bequeathing our children a deficit in the form of massive deferred maintenance on our infrastructure. That looks like overt criticism of George Osborne's deficit reduction plan. Now Larry Summers, former US treasury secretary, is asked whether the huge monetary stimulus programmes did any good. He says they helped avoid a repeat of the Great Depression. The last four years have been nothing like the 1929-1933 period - that's a tribute to the decisions taken by president Obama and in other countries around the world, says Summers. If you had known at the start of the crisis how bad it would be, people would have expected much more protectionism than we've seen, adding: ﻿I give credit to our British friends for the London summit in March 2009 where that principle was established. That's a tribute to Gordon Brown, the former UK PM, who organised that summit. Onto Japan's central bank governor, Haruhiko Kuroda -- should we be concerned that the looming sales tax hike will scupper the Japanese recovery? Kuroda argues that it will not, as monetary policy has taken account of the looming sales tax rise. Japan's economy is growing at 3% - so even after the sales tax takes place, in 2 stages, the economy will still grow at 1% to 1.5% percent, which is well over Japan's medium term trend, Kuroda says. But could it be reversed if it does cause problems? Kuroda says that it's natural to expect households to spend more before the tax rise occurs, and then spend less afterwards. So, no knee-jerk reaction. So are you sleeping more easily, chancellor? Osborne replies that: There's a huge amount to be done to fix the damage done by the great recession, and to avoid the mistakes of the past. Cutmore asks George Osborne to comment on Mark Carney's interview last night where he said interest rates would not rise anytime soon in the UK, even though the unemployment rate is near the 7% threshold in Carney's forward guidance. I'm not his boss, for one thing, says Osborne, and he can't comment on monetary policy -- that's the MPC's job. The fact we're discussing exiting stimulus is a sign of success, it's a sign of an economy taking off. We are only having this discussion because the recovery is underway, unemployment is falling, says Osborne. However the job is not done, it's not even half-done, Osborne adds -- we need to work on ways of moving to a situation where businesses provide more investment to stimulate the economy. And the Bank of England have tools to prevent a housing bubble. Haruhiko Kuroda is the man sharpening the tips of Japanese prime minister Abe's arrows, Cutmore adds. Introducing the panel, CNBC's Geoff Cutmore jokes that George Osborne picked Mark Carney to run the Bank of England because he realised you need a foreign manager to get success. And look, the economy is growing and unemployment is falling. OK, the first session on the future of monetary policy is starting now. It's being streamed live here. If you've not already enjoyed it, do check out Larry and Jill's report of a session yesterday at Davos on meditation, led by US actress Goldie Hawn. ﻿Two bits of advice are being offered to those gazing at their difficult thoughts. Do not try to hide away from the problem and equally do not try to explode it like a time bomb. Much better to let it melt away – "slowly melting like the frost under the morning sun". And breathe ... Goldie Hawn and a monk teach meditation to the elite In Davos, Chile's finance minister is insisting that his country can ride out any turmoil from neighbours, such as Argentina's currency crisis. The BBC's Alice Baxter has the details: Something different from George Soros this year, at his traditional dinner at the WEF last night (reports Larry Elliott) Normally, the Davos faithful flock to hear what the legendary financier thinks will be the next global currency to tank. This year, though, Soros used his dinner to focus exclusively on the humanitarian crisis in Syria, where the civil war has caused untold suffering. Soros said: "International governance has failed." "We can't ignore the victims. The attention of the global community is lacking in Syria. It is a human catastrophe of the first order." Soros said international public opinion could affect the behaviour of the Assad regime, which he accused of pursuing a policy of "surrender or starve". Yesterday's speech by Australian prime minister Tony Abbott has caused a political storm back home -- the opposition Labor party are furious that it included criticism of its fiscal policy while in office. As Katharine Murphy explains: Labor had delivered a stimulus package during the global financial crisis, and kept spending, because the then government had a philosophy of “spending its way to prosperity”, the prime minister argued. The new Coalition government in Canberra was pro-market and small government. There is a convention in Australian politics that domestic issues stay at home when leaders embark on overseas visits, and Labor on Friday argued Abbott would be better placed to respect it. Tony Abbott ‘embarrassing’ in Davos, says Bill Shorten Hello from Davos, Switzerland, where day three of the World Economic Forum is getting underway. There's a packed list of speakers today -- kicking off with a debate on the future of monetary policy in under an hour, at 9am Swiss time (8am GMT). UK chancellor George Osborne, Japan's finance minister central bank governor Haruhiko Kuroda, Brazil's Alexandre Tombini, Swiss central bank chairman Thomas Jordan, and professor Larry Summers are all on the panel. Hopefully they'll give views on the alarming tumble in the Argentinian peso's value this week. That's followed by David Cameron's special address (10.30am Swiss time). Al Gore, Ban Ki-moon, and Bill Gates are all on a panel discussing growth and development at 11am. At 12, Wolfgang Schauble, Germany's finance minister, discusses the outlook for Germany. And in the afternoon we get special addresses from Brazilian president Dilma Rousseff (2.15pm), US secretary of state John Kerry (5.15pm) and ECB president Mario Draghi (6pm).
fields.headline: Davos 2014: World Economic Forum - Day Three as it happened
fields.trailText: David Cameron tells Davos that Western firms can reshore jobs lost abroad through globalisation, and argued Europe must take advantage of shale gas

webTitle: O2 locks customers into higher prices after changing contract terms

fields.standfirst: Hours after regulator's new rules on switching came into force, O2 announced a 2.7% price hike and a clause in its contracts under which customers will forfeit the right to walk away
fields.body:
Millions of mobile phone subscribers will be handed contracts locking them into annual price rises after O2, the second largest British operator, changed its terms and conditions despite new rules designed to protect consumers.

From Thursday, all customers were supposed to be able to leave their phone or broadband provider without penalty if their tariff was increased midway through a fixed-term contract, after a crackdown by the telecoms watchdog Ofcom.

But the regulator's victory on behalf of households squeezed by the rising cost of living appears to have been shortlived. Hours after the new rules came into force, O2 announced a 2.7% price hike and a clause in its contracts under which customers will forfeit the right to walk away. Critics said that if other operators follow suit, Ofcom's reform will have succeeded only in locking yearly inflation in for consumers.

webTitle: Cairn Energy: tax authorities tell oil company to hold shares in Cairn India

fields.standfirst: Edinburgh-based business unable to proceed with sale of stake in Cairn India to mining company Vedanta
fields.body:
Cairn Energy, the British oil company that clashed with Greenpeace after pioneering a new spate of drilling in Arctic waters off Greenland, has run into trouble with the tax authorities in India.

The Edinburgh-based business, run by former Scottish rugby star Bill Gammell, confirmed it was currently unable to proceed with an almost $1bn (£600m) sale of its stake in Cairn India to mining company Vedanta.

Shares in Cairn fell 4% after the company admitted that money expected to be used in a series of wells in the North Sea and elsewhere was frozen pending the Indian investigation.

It said: "While discussions are ongoing, the income tax department has instructed Cairn Energy PLC to hold its shares in Cairn India."

webTitle: Royal Mail performance boosted by strong parcel demand over Christmas

fields.bodyText: More people sending Christmas cards and higher revenue from parcels helped Royal Mail achieve solid business over the first Christmas since the company floated on the stock market. The group said underlying sales for the nine months to the end of December rose 2%, helped by strong parcel demand and a rise in stamped mail over the month. Parcel volumes were flat over the nine months but rose during December. Parcels are important for Royal Mail because it is an area of the business that has been benefiting from the growth in online shopping, while letter sales are falling because of increased use of email and social media. In UK parcels, revenue was up 8% over the nine months as Royal Mail charged more for bigger items. Although consumer volumes fell as people held off posting big items made more expensive by the size-based pricing, sales to businesses rose. The company also blamed lack of parcel volume growth on wary business customers going elsewhere during a now settled dispute with the CWU union. Like-for-like letter sales fell 3% over the nine-month period but stamped mail, mainly Christmas cards, was up in December. The company said it was trading in line with its own expectations and was on track for its full-year targets. Royal Mail floated on the stock market in October in the biggest privatisation for many years. The sale has been criticised as short-changing the taxpayer after the shares surged far beyond the float price. Royal Mail shares rose in early trading but closed 15p lower at 573p following the figures – a 74% premium on the 330p float price. The share price performance since the flotation continues to prompt accusations that it was sold too cheaply. The chief executive, Moya Greene, said: "We remained the nation's number one parcel delivery company, handling 115m parcels in the month of December alone. That's significantly more than any other carrier in the UK parcel market. "Our financial performance to date is in line with our expectations and gives us confidence that we will deliver against our key value drivers for the full year." Greene could be in line for an increase in her £1.5m-a-year salary after the company's chairman, Donald Brydon, suggested earlier this week that she was underpaid for the boss of a FTSE 100 company. However, the government indicated that it might block any large increases in executive pay. Analysts were generally positive about prospects for the business. John Lawson at Investec said: "Royal Mail has made a good start as a listed entity and the statement indicated that the underlying trading trends are largely as we expected. Christmas is always a challenging period for the group and without any major weather hindrance Royal Mail has successfully navigated this peak season. Stay with it." Gert Zonneveld at Panmure Gordon said: "Following a strong share price performance, we have downgraded our recommendation from buy to hold. While we continue to see longer-term upside potential in the share price, especially if we assume that the dividend payout ratio is likely to increase, in the near term we expect the shares to tread water. We maintain our target price of 570p."
